1.c: highly congested with cosmopolitan population. Heavy assessment. Old and poor housing. Shifting population
1.b: Near central Boston employment area. Good schools, transportation, etc.

areaDesc.5: Houses used primarily for rooming house purposes. Mass. Ave. and Wecester Square are the best of the section with some kitchenette suites bringing $100 for entire house. A few scattered singles have been converted to apartments. Area becomes less desirable north of Dover St. with Orientals concentrated in this spot. Portion west of Tremont is quite desirable - exception being Springfield St. which is solid negro. Between Columbus Ave. and the railroad north of Rutland are houses sellinh $1,500-2,500 housing all negro.

1.c: inconvenient to transportation. Obsolescence
1.b: Desirable location of older houses well held - good elevation. Some scattered new construction

areaDesc.5: new construction concentrated near the Milton line; selling around $8,000. The houses along Metropolitan and Milton Streets near Summit are very desirable and much better than the balance of the area.

1.c: Highly congested. Foreiign concentration. Narrow streets. Low wage class. Scattered taverns.
1.b: Good transportation. Near employment. Convenient to everything.
1.a: This area is similar in all respects to area "D-5" but is separated by the business section which is growing up between the two areas. South of Cambridge St. the neighborhood improves slightly as it abuts area "C-4". The general trend, however, is downward with business encroachment threatening to absorb the entire area north of Cambridge St. eventually.

areaDesc.5: One of the older sections of Boston with brick tenements and old singles houses on narrow irregular streets. An elevated railway runs along Atlantic Ave. and Causeway St. The neighborhood is considered to be "tough: annd juvenille delinquincy is a definite problem. No immigration to replace those occupants who moved out. Demolition caused increase in rents.

1.c: Industrial encroachment. Obsolescence. Slum sections. Poor and old housing
1.b: Proximity to Boston commercial area. Near industrial employment

areaDesc.5: The general trend of desirability has been down in this part of Boston for some time. Industrial encroachment has completely circled the area and continues to take up additional ground, especially near the waterfront. Around Monument Square on the south side are quite desirable brick and brownstone bouses which are better than the section as a whole.

1.c: Obsolescence
1.b: Good transportation. Close to central Boston. Convenient to beaches.

areaDesc.5: This is a good workingman's neighborhood with little regularity is construction or grouping in types of houses. The general trend is down as lower class of occupant is slowly moving in. The neighborhood is not pleasing in appearance.

1.c: congested. Heavy traffic. Large assessments. Unimproved property. Poor housing. Cosmopolitan population. Obsolescence.
1.b: good transportation, schools, etc. close to central Boston employment area

areaDesc.5: Negro heavily concentrated north of Ruggles St. on the west side of Washington. Jewish centered near Columbus Square. A large territory with some streets showing better experiences than the balance of the section.

1.c: obsolescence. Congestion. Heavy traffic
1.b: good transportation, schools, churches, etc. Strong Catholic influence

areaDesc.5: There is scattered business throughout the area. Some scattered alley properties. Recent construction (within 10 years) was poorly occupied

1.c: obsolescence. Threatening lower class encroachment
1.b: good transportation, schools, churches, shopping center. Fairly desirable section of older houses.

1.c: obsolescence - foreign infiltration
1.b: good transportation, schools

areaDesc.5: Boynton Street is very mediocre. Mortgages are more readily available on single houses. A borderline section having a general mixture of houses, some of which are very good.

1.c: obsolescence - shifting population _____ from South end.
1.b: Near Franklin Park. Good transportation, schools, churches, etc.

areaDesc.5: Properties on Orchard Avenue are good. A few 3-family houses in poor condition precently sold for $2,500 apiece.

1.c: poor housing. Business scattered throughout.
1.b: good transportation, schools, etc. convenient to beach. Near employment.

areaDesc.5: There are many block tenement houses helf for income purposes.

1.c: nominal. Obsolescence.
1.b: desirable section of good houses with all conveniences. Rapid transit
1.a: hilly in southern part - level in north

areaDesc.5: A very conservative area with all convenience which is feeling a return of many buyers who moved into other sections. The southern end of this section has the newer singles and two-family units of smaller size and is the more active portion, although the entire area enjoys a fairly good reputation locally.

1.c: obsolescence. Limited market on sales.
1.b: good transportation, schools, churches, etc. Adjacent to Franklin Park with free facilities.

areaDesc.5: This area has been predominantly Jewish for several years. Mortgage financing is limited but funds are available through channels outside.

1.c: Market limited to Jewish buyers
1.b: Considered high class Jewish section with good transportation, schools, shopping centers, etc. Near Franklin Park with free facilitaties.

areaDesc.5: This area has been predominantly Jewish for several years and market is now limited to this buyer. Mortgage funds are limited because of occupants but financing is no problem on sales.

1.c: nominal
1.b: new and modern houses of modest size

1.c: Obsolescence - changing population. General mixture of houses.
1.b: good transportation, schools, etc. Fairly desirable residential section.

areaDesc.5: There are apartments of all sizes scattered throughout the area and concentrated on Commonwealth Ave. and eastern part on the main streets. The higher rentals on 3 family units are for heated apartments. In the Strathmore and Sutherland area the properties with large lots are being demolished and replaced with good apartments, kitchenettes. The general character of Brighton and Allston is fair, but the trend is slowly downward with a gradual change in type of housing accommodations and occupants.

1.c: Shifting population. Lower class encroachment. Mediocre houses scattered throughout
1.b: fair transportation, schools, churches, etc. Near some local employment.
1.a: level near railroad - rolling to hillside further back

4.a: limited, except on newer singles and 2- family

areaDesc.5: the more desirable part of the section is north of Fairmont Street off River Street. Annexed to Boston about 1915-1918.

1.c: Steep ascent into southern piece.
1.b: Desirable 3-family section of modest size. Good transportation, schools, etc.

4.a: yes, on singles, somewhat limited on 2 family

areaDesc.5: This area is situated on top of two separate hills and protected thus from the 3rd grade area around it. Houses are fairly modern and the neighborhood continues as a desirable one.

1.c: Unrestricted. Many unfinished streets. Some shack-type housing
1.b: Fair section in sparsely developed country atmosphere. Fair bus transportation

areaDesc.5: Area could develop into desirable neighborhood but its future is doubtful in view of the class of real estate already built. Foreign concentrated off Washington St. between LaGrange and Grove. German population off Washington below Grove.

1.c: Speculative building. Small lots.
1.b: New and modern section of modest houses. Fair transportation - good school. Restricted to single houses.

areaDesc.5: Although these are new houses, the development was poorly planned and some of the houses are not too well constructed. The lots are too small for a high class development.

1.c: Some Jerry-built houses. Distance to center of Boston. Scattered old houses
1.b: country atmosphere. Fair transportation.

1.c: Obsolescence. Threatening encroachment of lower class occupants. Very congested.
1.b: Good transportation, schools, churches, etc. Fairly desirable section although somewhat old. Good rental area.

areaDesc.5: The more desirable part of this area is on the west side of the railroad tracks above Centre St. Foreign element is concentrated in the poorer properties north of Henly playground to Forest Hills station

1.c: Some older houses interspersed through the area.
1.b: Desirable neighborhood of good homes. Near Parks and Arboretum.

areaDesc.5: There are a few houses along the parkway which are valued up to $60,000 although some doubt exists as to their ever selling at that price.

1.c: Heavy traffic. Congestion.
1.b: good transportation, schools, churches, etc. Convenient location. Near Fenway.
1.a: level - gradual upward slope to the southwest

areaDesc.5: Predominently a section of middle class apartment house dwellers, many of whom are nurses or students in Harvard and other colleges (Medical) in the area. There are also many rooming houses and furnished housekeeping units in the section. High class apartments along Riverway Parkway, renting $90-150 for 7-room apartments, north of Deaconess and west of Brookline Ave. eliminating frontage on Brookline.

1.c: obsolescence. Shifting population. Transition from owner occupany to transient and rooming house occupants. Increasing congestion.
1.b: convenient location to downtown Boston. Near Boston Common and Public Garden

a.3: hotels - apartments - clubs - fraternity houses - private schools

areaDesc.5: Mortgage financing is limited as to purpose. Houses purchased for single house occupancy can be financed at reasonable terms but income properties are difficult to finance. For residential purposes the 3 story houses are the most desirable. The area is changing and fairly rapidly into a rooming house neighborhood with doctors and clubs taking over many of the units. The poorer part of this section is along Newberry St.

1.c: Obsolescence. Large mixed houses
1.b: Old and still fairly desirable neighborhood with good houses convenient to transportation. Zoned for single houses.

areaDesc.5: New houses are being built on ground of demolished units. Ground values are 50 cents a foot and these prices are helping to hold up class of replacement units. Originally the finest section of Brookline with many old families still living in large houses and estates.

1.c: narrow streets. Congested and closely built houses
1.b: convenient location within walking distance of everything. Near Boston Common and Public Garden

areaDesc.5: Considerable reconditioning has been done in this area. Some houses being converted to apartments, others being used for rooming houses. Generally speaking the properties are very substantial and the neighborhood is expected to hold up fairly well.

1.c: Obsolescence. Some houses have no baths.
1.b: Fairly desirable section of modest houses in good demand. Near beach and playground. Good transportation, schools, etc. Year-around public bath house on waterfront.

2.a: clerks, mechanics, local businessmen - public employees

areaDesc.5: Much of this property is fairly well held. Boulevard frontages are considered the most desirables and have the better properties. There are a few units in this area without baths which rent for as low as $18.

1.c: Obsolescence. Hilly is southern end.
1.b: Fair section, old houses in fair demand. Good transportation, schools, etc. Near beach and playground.

areaDesc.5: Mortgage financing is available only from So. Boston banks and they are not anxious to loan above Broadway on any property and at 60% maximum below. Coal dust is blown into the northern part of the area from the yards along the waterfront. Houses on Telegraph Hill are considered more favorably located than the others in this area.

1.c: very poor property, many houses without baths. Congested area. Vandalism.
1.b: good transportation, schools, etc. Convenient to diversified employment. Within walking distance of downtown Boston

areaDesc.5: Vale St. is fair and houses with conveniences will rent up to $25. Part of this area was approved for a slum clearance project, which has been built below Hyde St. between the railroad and Columbia Road. There are many alley properties built as narrow so-called streets. Dorchester St. to Broadway has good houses, which are declining in desirability now used as doctors' offices.

1.c: mixture of houses and business. Low class occupants
1.b: good transportation, schools, etc. Convenient to employment in the vicinity.

areaDesc.5: Negro concentrated around Empire St. The better 3-family units are heated, and rentals include such. Some very poor tenament houses are scattered throughout. Originally a good section with some large hoouses now given over to rooming house use.

1.c: Highly congested. Foreiign concentration. Narrow streets. Low wage class. Scattered taverns.
1.b: Good transportation. Near employment. Convenient to everything.
1.a: hillside to Cambridge St. - level to north

areaDesc.5: One of the older sections of Boston with brick tenements and old singles houses on narrow irregular streets. An elevated railway runs along Atlantic Ave. and Causeway St. The neighborhood is considered to be "tough: annd juvenille delinquincy is a definite problem. No immigration to replace those occupants who moved out. Demolition caused increase in rents.

1.c: Obsolescence. Threatening encroachment of lower class people
1.b: near employment. Good transportation and schools. Near central Boston

areaDesc.5: Original owners of large singles have moved out and houses have been converted to small apartments with second floor units renting for about $2 more that 1st or 3rd floor

1.c: low class populace. Congested area. Area is reported unsafe after dark.
1.b: Near diversified employment. Good transportation and schools. Close to central Boston

areaDesc.5: General trend is down with prices continuing to descend. Rent collections are very difficult and the character of the neighborhood is deteriorating.

1.c: obsolescence. Distance to high school.
1.b: single trolley fare to any part of Boston

areaDesc.5: The few streets south of the railroad tracks to Winthrop are generally better than the balance of the neighorhood and houses in this area will bring top prices. The section is very attractive to people who want to live in E. Boston. The single houses are good, although somewhat poorly located.

1.c: Backing up to cemeteries.
1.b: small but well planned development of good houses in desirable neighborhood. Convenient to transportation yet out of traffic.

areaDesc.5: New construction being put on occasional lots.

1.c: none
1.b: rapid transit. New and modern houses in favorable location. Good schools, churches, etc.

areaDesc.5: New construction selling $7,500-10,000. Threatening Jewish infiltration into area.
